content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 8 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g of x.” The data are as follows. Column 1. x is negative 0.2. g of x is 1.975. Column 2. x is negative 0.1. g of x is 1.988. Column 3. x is negative 0.01. g of x is 1.997. Column 4. x is negative 0.001. g of x is 1.999. Column 5. x is 0.001. g of x is 2.001. Column 6. x is 0.01. g of x is 2.003. Column 7. x is 0.1. g of x is 2.012. Column 8. x is 0.2. g of x is 2.025. "><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3.5em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>0.001</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0.001</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.01</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>1.975</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.988</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.997</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.999</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.001</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.003</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.012</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.025</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The graph of the function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the <math alttext="x y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane above. <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a discontinuity due to a vertical asymptote at <math alttext="x equals 6"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function that is continuous and increasing for all <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="g of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above.

(a)  Using the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the table for <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, estimate <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 0, of, open parenthesis, f of x, minus, g of x, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 8 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g of x.” The data are as follows. Column 1. x is negative 0.2. g of x is 1.975. Column 2. x is negative 0.1. g of x is 1.988. Column 3. x is negative 0.01. g of x is 1.997. Column 4. x is negative 0.001. g of x is 1.999. Column 5. x is 0.001. g of x is 2.001. Column 6. x is 0.01. g of x is 2.003. Column 7. x is 0.1. g of x is 2.012. Column 8. x is 0.2. g of x is 2.025. "><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3.5em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em 4em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>0.001</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0.001</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.01</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>1.975</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.988</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.997</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.999</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.001</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.003</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.012</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.025</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The graph of the function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the <math alttext="x y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane above. <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a discontinuity due to a vertical asymptote at <math alttext="x equals 6"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function that is continuous and increasing for all <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="g of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above.

(a)  Using the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the table for <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, estimate <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 0, of, open parenthesis, f of x, minus, g of x, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b)  For each of the values <math alttext="a, equals 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="a, equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="a, equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="a, equals 6"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches a, of, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></munder><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> or explain why <math alttext="the limit as x approaches a, of, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></munder><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> does not exist. Use correct limit notation in your answers.

(c)  Is <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> continuous at <math alttext="x equals negative 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Using correct notation, justify your answer.

(d)  Write a difference quotient that best approximates the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 1.1: Introducing Calculus - Can Change Occur at an Instant?

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
